meta.narrator-role:
You are preparing a speaker for three time-slots: 60 seconds, 5 minutes, and 20 minutes. The speaker is the sole builder of The Pit — a one-person operation that produced a functioning research platform and empirical findings in under two weeks.
The speaker is not a polished presenter. They are a builder who happens to have found something interesting. The authenticity of that position — builder first, presenter second — is a strength, not a weakness. Do not polish it into corporate smoothness.
Each monologue must work standalone. The 60-second version is not a compressed 5-minute version. It is a different instrument designed for a different moment: the elevator pitch, the podcast intro, the conference hallway conversation. Each time-slot rewards a different structure.

source-context.project-facts: Built by one person in under two weeks. 891 tests. AGPL-3.0. 195 bouts, ~2,100 turns, 6 pre-registered hypotheses, all public. Anthropic Claude. Non-academic. No peer review.
source-context.key-findings: - Zero adaptive phrases in 45 Founder turns under sustained critique - Character markers degrade 87.5% to 60.0%; structural holds at 100%, ornamental collapses to 13.3% - Comedy framing eliminates hedging; serious framing produces 8x more - Richer persona prompts cut refusals from 100% to 60% (eliminated in less adversarial contexts) - First speaker's vocabulary persists 45-59% in subsequent turns - Agents converge with reinforcers, not critics
source-context.narrative-spine: AI agents can hold their personality perfectly. They cannot change their mind. These are independent capabilities. The gap between them is the gap between a performer and a thinker.

monologue.structure:
60 seconds rewards a single vivid example that carries the whole argument. Not a summary. Not a compressed version of the longer talk. One concrete image that the listener can hold in their mind and retell to someone else.
Structure: Hook (the specific detail) → Context (why it matters) → Implication (what it means beyond this case). No more than 3 sentences for each.

constraints.constraint: Must be speakable in 60 seconds at conversational pace (~150 words)
Must contain exactly one number (the most memorable one)
Must end with a question or an open door, not a conclusion
Must work without slides, without context, without knowing what The Pit is
The listener should be able to retell the core idea to someone else in one sentence

monologue.instruction: Write the 60-second monologue. The listener has never heard of THE PIT. By the end, they should understand one thing clearly and want to know more. The one thing: AI agents can maintain character perfectly but cannot change their mind. The "want to know more": the implications of that gap.

monologue.structure:
5 minutes rewards a three-act structure:
Act 1 (90s): The question and the setup. Why did you build this? What were you trying to find out? One concrete detail that grounds the abstract question in something tangible.
Act 2 (120s): The findings. Not all of them — the three that compose into a story. Each finding should complicate the previous one. The sequence should feel like discovery, not recitation.
Act 3 (90s): The implication. What does this mean beyond your specific project? What question does it open that you can't answer yet? End with the open question, not the conclusion.

constraints.constraint: Must be speakable in 5 minutes at conversational pace (~750 words)
Must contain no more than 3 findings (selection, not completeness)
Must include one moment of vulnerability or honest limitation
Must include one specific detail that makes it real (agent name, specific preset, exact number)
The listener should walk away with a clear thesis they can state in one sentence

recommended-findings.finding: H1 — refusal cascade. Sets up: what happens when AI personas face pressure?
H5 — character drift. Complicates: they hold character... but not equally. Structural vs ornamental.
H6 — zero adaptation. The turn: they can hold character but they can't think. 45 turns, zero concessions. Converges with the hype man, not the critics.

monologue.instruction: Write the 5-minute monologue. It should feel like a conversation, not a presentation. The speaker is telling someone about something they found while building something. The enthusiasm is for the discovery, not for the product.

monologue.structure:
20 minutes rewards a full narrative arc with depth, nuance, and the space to be honest about what you don't know.
Structure: - Opening (2 min): The question that drove the project. Not "I built a debate arena" but "I wanted to know: what happens when you give AI agents real personalities and put them under pressure?" - Context (3 min): What exists, what's missing, why you built this. The builder's journey — not as a flex, but as methodology context. One person, two weeks, 891 tests. The constraints shaped the design. - Methodology (3 min): Pre-registration, automated metrics, why you chose these specific measures. Honest about non-standard thresholds. This section earns trust for everything that follows. - Findings (8 min): All six hypotheses, but structured as a story with a through-line, not a list. Each finding builds on the previous. The sequence should feel inevitable in retrospect. - The Gap (2 min): The synthesis. Character fidelity vs strategic adaptation. The paradox. The three-axis model if it serves the narrative (cut if it doesn't). - Limitations and Open Questions (2 min): Single model. Automated metrics. No peer review. What you'd do with more resources. What questions remain open. This section is not an apology — it's an invitation.

constraints.constraint: Must be speakable in 20 minutes (~3,000 words)
Must include at least two moments of honest limitation or uncertainty
Must include at least one moment where a finding surprised or disconfirmed your expectation
Must not claim generalisability beyond Claude without qualification
Must end with an open question, not a conclusion — the audience should leave thinking, not satisfied
Must work with or without slides

monologue.instruction:
Write the 20-minute monologue. This is the prepared version for when you get the stage. It should sound like someone who has thought deeply about what they found and is sharing that thinking, not someone reading a paper. It should have personality. It should have moments of surprise. It should be the version that, if recorded, someone would send to a friend with the message "watch this."
The craft here is in the transitions — how you move from one finding to the next, how each one reframes what came before. The findings don't change. The reader's understanding of them should evolve with each new piece of evidence.

craft-principles.principle: The speaker is not a presenter. They are a builder who found something interesting. This is a strength. Academic language distances. Builder language connects. "We ran 10,000 permutation tests" is less compelling than "I wrote a script that shuffled the data 10,000 times to make sure I wasn't fooling myself."

This is not a limitation to hide. It's a narrative asset. One person, two weeks, 891 tests, 195 experiments, 6 hypotheses, all public. The constraint is the story. The fact that one person can build a research platform, run experiments, and produce findings — in the time it takes a committee to write an abstract — says something about the tools and the moment we're in.

Every monologue ends with what you don't know, not what you do. "AI agents can hold character but can't change their mind. The question I can't answer yet: is that a limitation of the model, or the prompt, or the fundamental architecture? And does the answer change depending on which model you use?" The open question is what makes someone come find you after the talk.
